name: 蕭佳芸
objective: In this course, we will develop proficiency in the dual arts of writing and editing. We will move from sentences to paragraphs to pages, from statements to arguments to essays. We will learn to write formally and to read each others’ work with a discriminating eye. The final project will be a polished research paper on a topic of your own choosing. Bring a pencil and a pen; you will be writing and editing in every class.
schedule:
Week 1: Introduction, Diagnostic Writing Exercise, Basics of Editing
Week 2: Style, “Understanding Style”—The Sentence
Week 3: Style, “Correctness”—The Paragraph
Week 4: Style, “Actions”—Logical Sequencing
Week 5: Style, “Characters,” “Cohesion and Coherence”—Point of View
Week 6: Style, “Emphasis,” “Concision”
Week 7: Style, “Shape”
Week 8: Style, “Elegance”
Week 9: Midterm Exam
Week 10: Style, “Motivating Coherence”—What Is an Argument?
Week 11: Style, “Global Coherence”—What Is Evidence?
Week 12: Style, “The Ethics of Style”—A Good Ending
Week 13: Making an Outline, Writing an Introduction
Week 14: Drafting Body Paragraphs
Week 15: Crafting a Conclusion	
Week 16: Footnotes
Week 17: Revising
Week 18: Hand in final essays
scorePolicy:
Grading Policy:

Attendance: 18 points

Writing Exercises: 18 points

Editing Exercises: 18 points

Midterm: 20 points

Final Essay: 30 points

Note that this totals 104; that means you have 4 free points to spend as you wish on absences and missed assignments.
materials: Textbook: Joseph M. Williams and Gregory G. Colomb, Style: Lessons in Clarity and Grace
